questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 24-hour history of severe lower abdominal pain. She has had two episodes of nonbloody vomiting today and has been unable to keep down food or fluids. She has not had a bowel movement since yesterday. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis. She had a cholecystectomy 5 years ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 20 years. Current medications include chlorthalidone, atorvastatin, and naproxen. Her temperature is 38.8°C (101.8­°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 94 kg (207 lbs); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Abdominal examination shows a soft abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds. There is moderate left lower quadrant tenderness. A tender mass is palpated on digital rectal examination. There is no guarding or rebound tenderness. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.3 g/dL


Hematocrit
40%


Leukocyte count
17,000/mm3


Platelet count
188,000/mm3



Serum



Na+

138 mEq/L


K+

4.1 mEq/L


Cl-

101 mEq/L


HCO3-

22 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
18.1 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


Which of the following is most appropriate to confirm the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is contraindicated in this patient with an acute episode of diverticulitis because the inflammation may be exacerbated by the procedure and the risk of perforation is increased. Colonoscopy is typically performed once the inflammation has subsided (typically after 6 weeks) to assess the extent of diverticulitis and rule out malignancy. Rectal cancer is an important differential diagnosis in a patient with a palpable mass on DRE. However, given the acute presentation with systemic signs of inflammation (fever, leukocytosis) and the tenderness of the mass, diverticulitis is more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasonography (US) can be performed if other imaging techniques are unavailable. Abdominal US would typically show diverticula, hypoechoic peridiverticular inflammation, abscess formations (detectable fluid), or bowel wall thickening. However, ultrasound is not the test of choice for the diagnosis of diverticulitis.
Image Description:

Ultrasound left lower quadrant (longitudinal plane)

Diverticula are visible as outpouchings (arrows) on the antimesenteric border of the sigmoid colon (dotted outline). The sigmoid is edematous, with a thickened wall, loss of distinction of mural layers, and narrowing of the lumen (wavy white line). Abnormally hyperechoic inflamed fat (yellow overlay) is also seen. A thin hypoechoic region along the mesenteric border (green overlay) may demonstrate free fluid.

The imaging features are suggestive of diverticulitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy may be considered in patients with severe abdominal pain that cannot be evaluated sufficiently by noninvasive diagnostic methods. This patient's clinical presentation strongly suggests diverticulitis, which can be confirmed or ruled out with a diagnostic test, rendering exploratory laparotomy unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Sigmoidoscopy should not be performed during an acute episode of diverticulitis because of an increased risk of exacerbating the inflammation or even bowel wall perforation. Once the inflammation has subsided, the colon should be assessed for the extent of diverticulitis and the presence of colorectal neoplasms. Although this procedure may be performed either via sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy, the latter is usually preferred as it enables evaluation of the entire colon.

E) CORRECT:

CT scan of the abdomen with contrast (oral and intravenous) is the test of choice for diagnosing diverticulitis. Typical CT findings include bowel wall thickening (> 4 mm) and inflammation of the pericolonic fat with fat stranding (visible traces of fluid in the fat). A CT scan is also helpful in ruling out complications such as abscess (fluid collections surrounded by inflammatory changes), obstruction (dilated intestinal loops, air-fluid levels), perforation (free air in the abdominal cavity), and fistula (air in organs other than the bowel).

The treatment of uncomplicated diverticulitis can usually occur in an outpatient setting. It includes a restricted, clear liquid diet and bowel rest until pain improves, broad-spectrum oral antibiotics for 7–10 days (e.g., ciprofloxacin plus metronidazole), and pain management, if necessary (e.g., acetaminophen, ibuprofen).
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with IV contrast; portal venous phase; axial and coronal planes) of an adult female patient with a history of lower abdominal pain and elevated inflammatory laboratory values

Numerous diverticula (examples indicated by red arrowheads) are present throughout the colon. Fatty and fascial inflammatory stranding (red overlay) are seen around one diverticulum (black arrowhead) and the wall of the sigmoid colon is thickened (green overlay) in this region. There is a small amount of adjacent free fluid (blue overlay in axial plane). Inflammatory changes are seen both inferior and superior to the thickened sigmoid segment.

The uterus is surgically absent. A small splenule (yellow overlay) is seen adjacent to the pancreatic tail.

F) INCORRECT:

Abdominal x-ray is not useful to confirm the diagnosis of diverticulitis, as it may fail to demonstrate the presence of colonic diverticula and the expected bowel wall thickening. However, it can be used to visualize some of the complications of diverticulitis, such as abscesses, obstructions, ileus, and perforation (pneumoperitoneum).
Image Description:

Double-contrast barium enema of the colon

Multiple diverticula in the colon can be seen (examples circled in green).
questions.hint: A tender left lower quadrant mass (indicating pericolonic inflammation) with leukocytosis and fever is consistent with acute diverticulitis. The inflamed diverticula that are situated in the distal sigmoid colon can be palpated on digital rectal examination (DRE).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of a 3-day history of left lower abdominal pain. During this period, the patient has also had a low-grade fever and has not had a bowel movement. He has a history of constipation. He underwent a cholecystectomy at the age of 53 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 30 years. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Abdominal examination shows left lower quadrant tenderness with no guarding or rebound. There is no edema of his lower extremities. CT of the abdomen with contrast shows segmental wall thickening of the descending colon with multiple diverticula, surrounding fat stranding, and a 5.5-cm, low-attenuating pelvic fluid collection. Intravenous fluids and bowel rest are started. Treatment with intravenous morphine, ciprofloxacin, and metronidazole is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation and serial imaging is not sufficient treatment for this patient with acute complicated diverticulitis. He has a 5.5-cm pelvic abscess that is unlikely to resolve solely with antibiotics and will require further intervention. Smaller (≤ 4.0-cm) abscesses will often respond to IV antibiotic therapy alone and may be followed with serial imaging until the abscess has resolved.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemicolectomy is rarely indicated in patients with complicated diverticulitis. If this patient required surgical intervention, segmental resection of the affected colonic part would be the appropriate surgical treatment. Although this patient has a pelvic abscess, he has no signs or symptoms of peritonitis that would mandate urgent colonic resection, and he has just been started on an appropriate antibiotic regimen.

C) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is contraindicated in patients with acute diverticulitis because of the increased risk of bowel perforation secondary to colonic mucosal irritation. After 6–8 weeks, once symptoms have subsided and the mucosal inflammation has resolved, colonoscopy should be performed to assess the extent of diverticulosis and to rule out malignancy.

D) CORRECT:

CT-guided percutaneous drainage is the treatment of choice for patients, like this one, with acute diverticulitis complicated by large abscesses and no indications for emergent surgery (e.g., signs of peritonitis). CT-guided drainage enables resolution of the abscess while minimizing the risk of complications from open surgery (e.g., colostomy, adhesions). Patients who respond to initial management but subsequently develop recurrent episodes of diverticulitis or chronic complications (e.g., fistulas) may be considered for elective colonic resection.

E) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy would usually be performed on a hemodynamically unstable patient as an emergent intervention. This patient is hemodynamically stable and does not have any signs of peritonitis. A less aggressive form of management is indicated at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Segmental colonic resection followed by primary anastomosis, or alternatively by Hartmann procedure, is indicated in complicated diverticulitis only if conservative management fails or if there are signs of peritonitis. This patient has a large simple pelvic abscess that does not require surgery.
questions.hint: This patient's history of constipation and left lower quadrant pain together with CT findings of segmental colonic wall thickening with multiple diverticula and surrounding fat stranding suggest acute diverticulitis. The > 4.0-cm low-attenuating fluid collection is consistent with a large pelvic abscess, which has developed as a complication of diverticulitis. There are no signs that suggest peritonitis (e.g., guarding, rebound tenderness, rigid abdomen). Intravenous antibiotics alone are highly unlikely to resolve this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. He has been taking over-the-counter supplements for constipation for the past 5 years. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. His current medications include metformin. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 134/82 mm Hg. Examination of the abdomen shows no masses. Palpation of the left lower abdomen elicits tenderness. A CT scan of the abdomen with oral contrast is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's condition?

choices.text: Focal weakness of the colonic muscularis layer
Infiltrative growth in the descending colon
Dysregulated immune response in the intestinal mucosa
Twisting of the sigmoid colon around its mesentery
Thrombosis of the inferior mesenteric vein

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Focal weakness of the colonic muscularis layer, typically at points where the vasa recta traverse the intestinal wall, allows for the formation of protrusions of mucosal and submucosal layers in response to increased intraluminal pressure (e.g., from chronic constipation). These protrusions are pseudodiverticula because not all layers of the intestinal wall are affected. Diverticulosis is the presence of these protrusions (identified as air-filled pouches on CT). Risk factors for diverticulosis include a low-fiber diet and smoking. The prevalence of diverticulosis also increases with age, which is thought to be because of structural changes in collagen associated with aging. Patients with connective tissue disorders such as Ehlers-Danlos, Marfan syndrome, and autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease may present with diverticula prematurely because they develop these structural changes earlier in life.

Diverticulitis, which is an inflammation of one or more of these protrusions, typically manifests with fever, left-sided lower abdominal pain, change in bowel habits (e.g., diarrhea), and bowel wall thickening on CT scan. Affected individuals may also have a tender, palpable mass if there is a peridiverticular abscess.
Image Description:

True diverticula affect all layers of the intestinal wall, including the muscular layer, while pseudodiverticula are only covered by a layer of mucosa and submucosa. Pseudodiverticula protrude at weak points of the muscular layer and are likely due to previously perforated intestinal vessels.

B) INCORRECT:

An infiltrative growth in the descending colon is consistent with left-sided colorectal cancer (CRC), which may manifest with changes in bowel habits (e.g., constipation, diarrhea) and abdominal pain. However, a CT scan usually shows a soft tissue density mass causing narrowing of the bowel lumen; adjacent air-filled pouches are not typical for CRC. Moreover, constipation for several years without a history of constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss) or features of metastatic disease is inconsistent with a diagnosis of CRC.

C) INCORRECT:

A dysregulated immune response in the intestinal mucosa is consistent with inflammatory bowel disease, such as Crohn disease or ulcerative colitis. Both of these conditions can cause disease flares that manifest with acute-onset low-grade fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. In addition, bowel wall thickening is common in both conditions, along with mesenteric fat stranding in Crohn disease. However, adjacent air-filled pouches are not typical for either condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Twisting of the sigmoid colon around its mesentery is consistent with sigmoid volvulus, which manifests with abdominal pain but would cause asymmetric abdominal distention and bowel obstruction rather than diarrhea. In addition, a CT scan typically shows gas-filled loops of bowel, twisting of the mesentery and mesenteric vessels (whirl sign), and gradual narrowing or tapering of the sigmoid colon up to the level of obstruction (bird beak sign), none of which are seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombosis of the inferior mesenteric vein can lead to acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI), which may manifest with abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, symptoms of venous AMI tend to develop over weeks rather than days. Moreover, although CT findings may include mesenteric fat stranding and bowel wall thickening and distention, air-filled pouches are not typical for AMI.
questions.hint: The patient's CT scan shows segmental thickening and enhancement of the colonic wall with air-filled pouches in the surrounding segments.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ischemic colitis can manifest with acute-onset nausea, diarrhea, and left lower quadrant abdominal pain (due to impaired blood flow to the rectosigmoid junction). However, diarrhea associated with this condition is characteristically bloody, and acute-onset ischemic colitis most commonly occurs in critically ill patients with hypotension.

B) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease (CD) is an inflammatory bowel disease that can manifest with fever, localized abdominal pain, and nausea. However, the pain associated with this condition typically manifests in the right lower quadrant, not the left lower quadrant, and is typically more insidious in nature. In addition, CD is associated with chronic diarrhea, not chronic constipation (though acute constipation can develop due to bowel obstruction).

C) INCORRECT:

Cholecystitis can manifest with acute-onset fever, localized abdominal pain, and nausea. However, the pain associated with this condition characteristically manifests in the right upper quadrant, not the left lower quadrant. In addition, cholecystitis is not associated with chronic constipation or acute changes in bowel habits.

D) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) can manifest with abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits (e.g., changes in stool frequency and/or appearance). However, these symptoms are typically chronic in nature and associated with bloating and distention. In addition, the pain associated with IBS is typically diffuse, not localized, and is not associated with fever.

E) INCORRECT:

Appendicitis can manifest with acute-onset fever, localized abdominal pain, nausea, and changes in bowel habits (e.g., diarrhea). However, the pain associated with appendicitis characteristically manifests in the periumbilical region and migrates to the right lower quadrant, not the left lower quadrant. In addition, appendicitis is not associated with chronic constipation.

F) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis (UC) is an inflammatory bowel disease that can manifest with fever, abdominal pain, and nausea. However, the pain associated with this condition is typically diffuse, not localized, and is more insidious in nature. In addition, UC is associated with chronic bloody diarrhea, not chronic constipation.

G) CORRECT:

Low-grade fever, nausea without vomiting, acute changes in bowel habits, and left lower quadrant abdominal pain are highly suggestive of diverticulitis. This condition can develop along any part of the colon but most commonly involves the sigmoid colon (which explains the localization of this patient's abdominal pain). Her history of constipation likely results in straining during bowel movements, which can lead to protrusion of herniated intestinal mucosa and submucosa through gaps in the muscular layer of the intestinal wall (i.e., diverticulosis). If stool gets lodged in the diverticula, this can result in obstruction of the intestinal lumen, increased intraluminal pressure, and subsequent erosion and inflammation of diverticular walls (i.e., diverticulitis). GI bleeding is a complication of diverticulosis (as a result of erosion of the intestinal vasa recta supplying the diverticulum) but is rare during an episode of acute diverticulitis because diverticular inflammation causes thrombosis in the vasa recta supplying the diverticulum.

This diagnosis is supported by clinical manifestations and the presence of increased serum inflammatory markers. A CT scan that shows inflamed diverticula, bowel wall thickening (> 4 mm), and/or inflammation of pericolic fat with fat stranding confirms the diagnosis. Uncomplicated diverticulitis (i.e., disease without abscess, bowel obstruction, perforation, or fistula) can be treated with supportive care and bowel rest.

Fatty and fascial inflammatory stranding (red overlay) are seen around one diverticulum (black arrowhead) and the wall of the sigmoid colon is thickened (green overlay) in this region. There is a small amount of adjacent free fluid (blue overlay in axial plane). Inflammatory changes are seen both inferior and superior to the thickened sigmoid segment.

The uterus is surgically absent. A small splenule (yellow overlay) is seen adjacent to the pancreatic tail.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain and fever. He also noticed air bubbles in his urine during this period. He has had three similar episodes of lower abdominal pain and fever with lesser intensity during the past 2 years. The patient says he is worried because “I never saw air in my urine before.” Medical history is remarkable for chronic constipation, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He underwent a colonoscopy 1 year ago, which showed focal outpouchings of the colonic wall in the sigmoid colon. Current medications include atorvastatin, metformin, and polyethylene glycol. Temperature is 38.3ºC (101.0ºF). Abdominal examination shows a tender palpable mass in the left lower quadrant. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following?

choices.text: Chronic inflammation of the bile ducts

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uveitis is a potential complication of Crohn disease (CD), which can result in a CVF. However, if the patient has CD, the previous colonoscopy would have shown evidence of this condition (e.g., ulcers, fissures, cobblestoning of the mucosa). This patient most likely developed the CVF as a result of diverticular disease, which is not associated with uveal inflammation.

B) CORRECT:

If left untreated, CVF predisposes the patient to recurrent urinary tract infections. Diverticulitis is the most common cause of CVF (65–80% of cases); localized inflammation of the peridiverticular tissue can result in the formation of a phlegmon or a diverticular abscess that can rupture into adjacent organs, creating a fistula. An abdominal CT scan with oral contrast is typically performed to confirm the diagnosis. In most patients with CVF, surgical repair is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Megaloblastic anemia due to impaired resorption of vitamin B12 is a potential complication of Crohn disease (CD), which can also result in a CVF. However, if the patient had CD, the previous colonoscopy would have shown evidence of this condition (e.g., ulcers, fissures, cobblestoning of the mucosa). Moreover, patients with CD typically present with a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant, whereas this patient has a mass in the left lower quadrant. This patient most likely developed the CVF as a result of diverticulitis, which may be associated with iron deficiency anemia due to chronic bleeding, but not with megaloblastic anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Metastatic liver disease is a complication of colon cancer, which can, on rare occasions, result in a CVF or an acute abdomen (due to colon perforation). This patient's history of chronic constipation and a palpable mass in the left lower quadrant might also raise suspicion for colon cancer. However, this patient's colonoscopy 1 year ago makes colon cancer unlikely; colon cancers typically develop in premalignant lesions (e.g.. adenomatous polyps) and only rarely arise de novo.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary sclerosing cholangitis, a form of chronic bile duct inflammation, is a potential complication of ulcerative colitis (UC) and, to a lesser extent, Crohn disease (CD). UC, however, is only associated with mucosal and submucosal inflammation and therefore does not typically result in fistula formation. Although CD is associated with transmural bowel inflammation and can result in a colovesical fistula, the previous colonoscopy would have shown evidence of this condition (e.g., ulcers, fissures, cobblestoning of the mucosa). This patient most likely developed the colovesical fistula as a result of diverticular disease, which is not associated with biliary inflammation.
questions.hint: This patient's history of recurrent episodes of fever and lower abdominal pain suggests diverticular disease complicated by diverticulitis. The presence of pneumaturia in a patient with diverticular disease indicates the formation of a colovesical fistula (CVF).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents for evaluation of left-sided abdominal pain that began 24 hours ago, accompanied by nausea and persistent vomiting. He recalls no prior episodes.
On examination, his temperature is 40°C, and his heart rate is 105 beats per minute. He is tender to abdominal palpation in the lower left quadrant, with some guarding and rebound.
CT of the abdomen shows the presence of diverticula and inflammation of the pericolic fat surrounding the sigmoid colon.
What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient’s care?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Emergency surgery for acute diverticulitis is usually only needed in frank perforation; urgent surgery is also indicated in the setting of obstruction, abscess that persists despite percutaneous drainage and/or antibiotic treatment, or lack of improvement after medical management alone.

B) INCORRECT:

A colonoscopy is not recommended in the acute setting because of the risk for perforation. A colonoscopy is typically performed about 6 weeks after the acute episode of complicated diverticulitis has resolved, to rule out conditions such as inflammatory bowel disease or cancer. If the patient has had a recent colonoscopy (within the past year), then the colonoscopy does not need to be repeated.

C) CORRECT:

Antibiotics are no longer recommended routinely for all patients with acute diverticulitis. Controlled trials in patients with uncomplicated diverticulitis (no abscess) showed no difference in outcomes between patients who received antibiotics and those who did not. However, antibiotics are recommended in cases of severe infection, sepsis, or complications. In this case, antibiotics are indicated because of the patient’s severe symptoms (persistent vomiting) and would need to be given intravenously to ensure adequate effect. Broad-spectrum antibiotics with gram-negative and anaerobic coverage are recommended as first-line therapy.

Key learning point: A patient with acute diverticulitis who has signs of severe infection or sepsis and who cannot tolerate oral intake of medication is best managed with intravenous antibiotic therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

CT-guided drain placement is used to manage pericolic abscesses of at least 4 cm in diameter.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics are no longer recommended routinely for all patients with acute diverticulitis. Controlled trials in patients with uncomplicated diverticulitis (no abscess) showed no difference in outcomes between patients who received antibiotics and those who did not. However, antibiotics are recommended in cases of severe infection, sepsis, or complications. In this case, antibiotics are indicated because of the patient’s severe symptoms (persistent vomiting) and would need to be given intravenously to ensure adequate effect, making oral antibiotic therapy inappropriate.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 29-year-old man is hospitalized with a 2-day history of moderate-to-severe lower abdominal pain associated with nausea and anorexia.
His temperature is 38.7°C, his heart rate is 107 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 109/69 mm Hg. He has tenderness in the left lower quadrant but no involuntary guarding or rebound tenderness.
CT of the abdomen and pelvis reveals a region of inflamed diverticula around the sigmoid colon, with wall thickening, inflammation of pericolic fat, subcentimeter mesenteric adenopathy, and a pericolic abscess 1.2 cm in diameter that is adjacent to the inflamed diverticulum. There is no evidence of bowel obstruction.
In addition to broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy and bowel rest, what is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s in-hospital care?

choices.text: Partial colectomy of the affected area and colonic reanastomosis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy should be performed within 6 weeks after the acute episode has resolved to evaluate for other processes, such as cancer or inflammatory bowel disease, which can mimic diverticulitis. Colonoscopy is not indicated in the short-term evaluation and management of acute diverticulitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous drainage is unnecessary when a pericolic abscess is 4 cm or less in diameter, unless the patient has peritonitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Colectomy with colonic reanastamosis is typically necessary if there are abscesses that contain gross feculent material or are associated with generalized peritonitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical drainage is typically necessary if there are abscesses that contain gross feculent material or are associated with generalized peritonitis.

E) CORRECT:

Observation is most appropriate in a patient who is being treated for acute diverticulitis and has a small pericolic abscess with no peritoneal signs on examination.

Key learning point: In addition to antibiotic therapy, the most appropriate in-hospital management for a patient with acute diverticulitis who has a pericolic abscess 1.2 cm in diameter and no peritoneal signs on examination is bowel rest and observation.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman with a medical history of obesity and hypertension presents to the emergency department with a 7-day history of pain in the left lower quadrant. Three days ago, she developed fevers, chills, nausea, and anorexia. She has no known drug allergies.
She appears ill and has a fever of 38.7°C. Her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is at her baseline of 124/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows voluntary guarding and exquisite tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant but no rebound tenderness.
A CT scan of the abdomen reveals evidence of diverticulitis and a 3-cm by 4-cm abscess adjacent to the inflamed sigmoid colon.
Which one of the following antibiotic regimens is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

When initiating treatment for community-acquired diverticular abscess, empiric therapy against Candida species (such as with fluconazole) is not necessary unless there is evidence for infection with this organism.

B) CORRECT:

Appropriate antimicrobial therapy for community-acquired diverticulitis of moderate severity with associated abscess formation should include agents active against enteric gram-negative aerobic bacilli, enteric gram-positive streptococci, and anaerobes. In a patient with severe diverticulitis, using an agent that also has anti-pseudomonal activity, such as piperacillin-tazobactam, meropenem, or imipenem, is recommended. See “Empiric antibiotics for intraabdominal infections” table.

Although some small abscesses that are not amenable to surgical drainage can be managed with antimicrobial therapy alone, most patients should undergo percutaneous drainage of the abscess or operative intervention.

Key learning point: Appropriate antimicrobial therapy for high-risk or high-severity community-acquired, complicated diverticulitis should be active against enteric gram-negative aerobic bacilli, enteric gram-positive streptococci, and anaerobes.

C) INCORRECT:

When initiating treatment for community-acquired diverticular abscess, empiric therapy against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (such as with vancomycin) is not necessary unless there is evidence for infection with this organism.

D) INCORRECT:

When initiating treatment for community-acquired diverticular abscess, empiric therapy against Candida species (such as with fluconazole) is not necessary unless there is evidence for infection with this organism.

E) INCORRECT:

Cefepime would be reasonable in combination with metronidazole but not with clindamycin. Clindamycin is not recommended for use in this setting because of increasing prevalence of resistance of Bacteroides fragilis.

Controlled trials in patients with uncomplicated diverticulitis (no abscess) showed no difference in outcomes between patients who received antibiotics and those who did not. However, antibiotics are recommended in cases of severe infection, sepsis, or complications. In this case, antibiotics are indicated because of the patient’s severe symptoms (persistent vomiting) and would need to be given intravenously to ensure adequate effect, making oral antibiotic therapy inappropriate.
questions.hint: A tender left lower quadrant and fever are consistent with acute diverticulitis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of nausea and severe lower abdominal pain. She has had two episodes of nonbloody diarrhea today. She has hypertension and chronic constipation. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6­°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Abdominal examination shows a soft abdomen with normal bowel sounds and left lower quadrant tenderness. There is no guarding or rebound tenderness. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.3 g/dL


Hematocrit
40%


Leukocyte count
17,000/mm3


Platelet count
188,000/mm3



Serum



Urea nitrogen
15.1 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to confirm the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is contraindicated in this patient with an acute episode of diverticulitis because the inflammation may be exacerbated by the procedure and the risk of perforation is increased. Colonoscopy is typically performed once the inflammation has subsided (typically after 6 weeks) to assess the extent of diverticulitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasonography (US) can be performed if other imaging techniques are unavailable. Abdominal US would typically show diverticula, hypoechoic peridiverticular inflammation, abscess formations (detectable fluid), or bowel wall thickening. However, ultrasound is not the test of choice for the diagnosis of diverticulitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Sigmoidoscopy should not be performed during an acute episode of diverticulitis because of an increased risk of exacerbating the inflammation or even bowel wall perforation. Once the inflammation has subsided, the colon should be assessed for the extent of diverticulitis.

D) CORRECT:

CT scan of the abdomen with contrast (oral and intravenous) is the test of choice for diagnosing diverticulitis. Typical CT findings include bowel wall thickening (> 4 mm) and inflammation of the pericolonic fat with fat stranding (visible traces of fluid in the fat). A CT scan is also helpful in ruling out complications such as abscess (fluid collections surrounded by inflammatory changes), obstruction (dilated intestinal loops, air-fluid levels), perforation (free air in the abdominal cavity), and fistula (air in organs other than the bowel).

The treatment of uncomplicated diverticulitis can usually occur in an outpatient setting. It includes a restricted, clear liquid diet and bowel rest until pain improves, broad-spectrum oral antibiotics for 7–10 days (e.g., ciprofloxacin plus metronidazole), and pain management, if necessary (e.g., acetaminophen, ibuprofen).
Image Description:

CT abdomen and pelvis (oral and IV contrast; coronal plane)

Mural thickening (green overlay) and luminal narrowing (red overlay) of the sigmoid colon are accompanied by fatty and fascial stranding, indicating a localized inflammatory process. When viewed on serial sections, multiple small, well-defined gas collections (arrowheads) represent inflamed sigmoid diverticula.

The features are characteristic of acute sigmoid diverticulitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominal x-ray is not useful to confirm the diagnosis of diverticulitis, as it may fail to demonstrate the presence of colonic diverticula and the expected bowel wall thickening. However, it can be used to visualize some of the complications of diverticulitis, such as abscesses, obstructions, ileus, and perforation (pneumoperitoneum).
questions.hint: Low-grade fever, nausea, acute changes in bowel habits, and left lower quadrant abdominal pain in a patient with chronic constipation are highly suggestive of diverticulitis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. He has been using over-the-counter supplements for constipation for the past 5 years. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago and has a 35-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. His current medication is metformin. His temperature is 38.4°C, pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 134/82 mm Hg. Abdominal examination reveals no masses, but there is tenderness on palpation of the left lower abdomen. A CT scan of the abdomen with oral contrast is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?

choices.text: Dysregulated immune response in the intestinal mucosa.
Focal weakness of the colonic muscularis layer.
Thrombosis of the inferior mesenteric vein.
Infiltrative growth in the descending colon.
Twisting of the sigmoid colon around its mesentery.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A dysregulated immune response in the intestinal mucosa is consistent with inflammatory bowel disease, such as Crohn disease or ulcerative colitis. Both of these conditions can cause disease flares that manifest with acute-onset low-grade fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. In addition, bowel wall thickening is common in both conditions, along with mesenteric fat stranding in Crohn disease. However, adjacent air-filled pouches are not typical for either condition.

B) CORRECT:

Focal weakness of the colonic muscularis layer, typically at points where the vasa recta traverse the intestinal wall, allows for the formation of protrusions of mucosal and submucosal layers in response to increased intraluminal pressure (e.g., from chronic constipation). These protrusions are pseudodiverticula because not all layers of the intestinal wall are affected. Diverticulosis is the presence of these protrusions (identified as air-filled pouches on CT). Risk factors for diverticulosis include a low-fiber diet and smoking. The prevalence of diverticulosis also increases with age, which is thought to be because of structural changes in collagen associated with aging. Patients with connective tissue disorders such as Ehlers-Danlos, Marfan syndrome, and autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease may present with diverticula prematurely because they develop these structural changes earlier in life.

Diverticulitis, which is an inflammation of one or more of these protrusions, typically manifests with fever, left-sided lower abdominal pain, change in bowel habits (e.g., diarrhea), and bowel wall thickening on CT scan. Affected individuals may also have a tender, palpable mass if there is a peridiverticular abscess.

Key learning point: Diverticulitis results from inflammation of colonic pseudodiverticula, which form at sites of focal muscularis weakness due to increased intraluminal pressure, especially in older adults with risk factors like chronic constipation and low-fiber diets.
Image Description:

True diverticula affect all layers of the intestinal wall, including the muscular layer, while pseudodiverticula are only covered by a layer of mucosa and submucosa. Pseudodiverticula protrude at weak points of the muscular layer and are likely due to previously perforated intestinal vessels.

C) INCORRECT:

Thrombosis of the inferior mesenteric vein can lead to acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI), which may manifest with abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, symptoms of venous AMI tend to develop over weeks rather than days. Moreover, although CT findings may include mesenteric fat stranding and bowel wall thickening and distention, air-filled pouches are not typical for AMI.

D) INCORRECT:

An infiltrative growth in the descending colon is consistent with left-sided colorectal cancer (CRC), which may manifest with changes in bowel habits (e.g., constipation, diarrhea) and abdominal pain. However, a CT scan usually shows a soft tissue density mass causing narrowing of the bowel lumen; adjacent air-filled pouches are not typical for CRC. Moreover, constipation for several years without a history of constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss) or features of metastatic disease is inconsistent with a diagnosis of CRC.

E) INCORRECT:

Twisting of the sigmoid colon around its mesentery is consistent with sigmoid volvulus, which manifests with abdominal pain but would cause asymmetric abdominal distention and bowel obstruction rather than diarrhea. In addition, a CT scan typically shows gas-filled loops of bowel, twisting of the mesentery and mesenteric vessels (whirl sign), and gradual narrowing or tapering of the sigmoid colon up to the level of obstruction (bird beak sign), none of which are seen here.
questions.hint: The patient's CT scan shows segmental thickening and enhancement of the colonic wall with air-filled pouches in the surrounding segments.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of left-sided abdominal pain that began 3 days ago, accompanied by nausea and persistent vomiting. He has not had similar episodes in the past. On examination, his temperature is 40°C and pulse is 105/min. There is tenderness to palpation in the lower left quadrant with guarding and rebound. CT of the abdomen shows diverticula, inflammation of the pericolic fat surrounding the sigmoid colon. There is a 1-cm pericolic abscess but no evidence of perforation. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT-guided drain placement is used to manage pericolic abscesses of at least 4 cm in diameter.

B) INCORRECT:

A colonoscopy is not recommended in the acute setting because of the risk for perforation. A colonoscopy is typically performed about 6 weeks after the acute episode of complicated diverticulitis has resolved, to rule out conditions such as inflammatory bowel disease or cancer. If the patient has had a recent colonoscopy (within the past year), then the colonoscopy does not need to be repeated.

C) INCORRECT:

Emergency surgery for acute diverticulitis is usually only needed in frank perforation; urgent surgery is also indicated in the setting of obstruction, abscess that persists despite percutaneous drainage and/or antibiotic treatment, or lack of improvement after medical management alone.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotic therapy is only considered for patients with uncomplicated diverticulitis who have certain risk factors for severe disease (e.g., pregnancy, diabetes mellitus, immunosuppression) and can tolerate oral intake of medication. In this case of complicated diverticulitis and persistent vomiting, antibiotics would need to be given intravenously to ensure adequate effect.

E) CORRECT:

Controlled trials in patients with uncomplicated diverticulitis showed no difference in outcomes between patients who received antibiotics and those who did not. For patients with uncomplicated diverticulitis, antibiotics are no longer routinely recommended and are only considered if certain risk factors for severe disease (e.g., pregnancy, diabetes mellitus, immunosuppression) are present. However, in cases of complicated diverticulitis, gram-negative and anaerobic coverage with broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics is recommended. CT-guided drain placement is used to manage pericolic abscesses ≥ 4 cm in diameter. Emergency surgery is indicated if there is evidence of perforation or generalized peritonitis.

Key learning point: Patients with complicated diverticulitis require intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy.
questions.hint: A tender left lower quadrant and fever are consistent with acute diverticulitis. The presence of a pericolic abscess indicates complicated diverticulitis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with diabetes and a history of diverticulosis presents with 3 days of left lower quadrant pain, nausea, and subjective fever. He appears uncomfortable but is hemodynamically stable. Physical examination shows left lower quadrant tenderness without rebound or guarding. Laboratory studies show a WBC count of 14,000/mm3, elevated C-reactive protein (160 mg/L), and a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL. CT of the abdomen shows sigmoid diverticulitis with extensive pericolic fat stranding and a 3-cm pericolic fluid collection. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Ciprofloxacin and metronidazole with outpatient follow-up
CT-guided percutaneous drainage of the fluid collection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics may be appropriate for uncomplicated diverticulitis, but this patient has diabetes, elevated inflammatory markers (CRP > 140 mg/L), and extensive inflammation with a fluid collection on CT, indicating complicated disease, which requires inpatient management.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has complicated diverticulitis (modified Hinchey stage Ib) with a pericolic abscess < 4 cm, diabetes, and elevated inflammatory markers. Inpatient management with IV antibiotics is recommended for all patients with complicated diverticulitis; this conservative approach without additional invasive management should be trialed for patients with abscesses < 4 cm.

C) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous drainage is typically reserved for abscesses ≥ 4 cm or patients who do not improve with conservative management with IV antibiotics after 48–72 hours. This patient's 3-cm collection should initially be managed conservatively.

D) INCORRECT:

Emergency surgical consultation is indicated for generalized peritonitis or sepsis, which are not present in this stable patient. The fluid collection represents localized inflammation rather than free perforation requiring immediate surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

Conservative management without antibiotics may be appropriate for uncomplicated diverticulitis in selected patients, but this patient has diabetes, elevated inflammatory markers, and CT evidence of complicated disease with abscess formation, which requires antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a two-day history of worsening left lower quadrant abdominal pain. The pain is constant and is associated with nausea and subjective fever. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg. Physical examination reveals focal tenderness to deep palpation in the left lower quadrant without peritoneal signs. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 14,500/mm3 with a neutrophilic predominance. Which of the following is the most appropriate imaging study to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A barium enema is contraindicated during an episode of acute diverticulitis. Similar to colonoscopy, the introduction of contrast material under pressure can cause perforation of an inflamed diverticulum, leading to spillage of barium and feces into the peritoneum. This can cause severe chemical and bacterial peritonitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasound may be considered in some cases of right lower quadrant pain, particularly to rule out gynecologic or appendiceal pathology. However, for suspected left-sided diverticulitis, its utility is limited by operator dependence and interference from overlying bowel gas. It is significantly less sensitive and specific for diagnosing diverticulitis and identifying its potential complications, such as a contained abscess.

C) INCORRECT:

An upright abdominal radiograph is primarily useful for detecting free intraperitoneal air, which would indicate a perforated viscus. However, it is insensitive for this finding and cannot directly visualize the colonic wall or surrounding soft tissues. In uncomplicated diverticulitis, as suspected in this patient without peritoneal signs, radiographs are typically normal and do not aid in confirming the diagnosis or grading its severity.

D) CORRECT:

CT of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast is the imaging modality of choice to confirm the diagnosis, assess the severity of inflammation, and rule out complications. Key findings include segmental bowel wall thickening (greater than 4 mm), pericolic fat stranding, and the presence of inflamed diverticula. Importantly, CT is crucial for identifying complications such as abscess formation, phlegmon, fistula, obstruction, or perforation (indicated by extraluminal air or fluid). This information is essential for appropriate management, determining the need for hospitalization, intravenous antibiotics, percutaneous drainage, or surgical intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

While colonoscopy is used to evaluate the colon and can identify diverticulosis, it is contraindicated in the setting of acute diverticulitis. The insufflation of air into the colon during the procedure increases intraluminal pressure, which can lead to perforation of the inflamed and weakened colonic wall. A colonoscopy is typically recommended 6-8 weeks after the resolution of an acute episode to rule out underlying malignancy.
questions.hint: This patient's constellation of left lower quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis is consistent with acute diverticulitis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of gradually worsening, constant, aching pain in her left lower abdomen. She reports associated nausea, loss of appetite, and a recent change in bowel habits with increased constipation. She has a history of hypertension. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness to deep palpation in the left lower quadrant with localized guarding, but no rebound tenderness. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 13,500/mm³ with a left shift. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian torsion is a cause of acute LLQ pain and nausea. However, the pain is typically of sudden, severe onset rather than gradually worsening over several days. Furthermore, ovarian torsion is uncommon in a 68-year-old postmenopausal woman due to ovarian atrophy. The presence of fever and leukocytosis also suggests another cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Colorectal carcinoma can cause LLQ pain and a change in bowel habits, such as constipation, in an older individual. However, cancer is typically a more chronic process. The acute presentation over 3 days with fever and marked leukocytosis strongly suggests an acute inflammatory or infectious condition rather than an underlying malignancy as the primary cause of the acute symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute pyelonephritis can cause fever, leukocytosis, and abdominal or flank pain. It typically also causes urinary symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency, as well as costovertebral angle tenderness on examination. The absence of these findings and the presence of primarily gastrointestinal symptoms make a renal cause less probable.

D) CORRECT:

Diverticulitis is the inflammation of a diverticulum, which most commonly occurs in the sigmoid colon and explains the manifestation with LLQ pain. This patient's clinical presentation, including the gradual onset of pain, low-grade fever, anorexia, and a change in bowel habits, is typical of diverticulitis. The physical examination finding of localized LLQ tenderness and laboratory results showing leukocytosis with a left shift further support an infectious or inflammatory process localized to this area. This condition results from a microperforation of a diverticulum, leading to pericolonic inflammation and infection. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast is the diagnostic imaging of choice.

E) INCORRECT:

Ischemic colitis can cause LLQ pain in an older adult, particularly in watershed areas like the splenic flexure. However, it typically manifests with a more sudden onset of cramping abdominal pain followed by hematochezia or bloody diarrhea. This patient's gradual onset of pain, constipation, and prominent signs of infection, such as fever and significant leukocytosis, make another condition more likely.
questions.hint: Left lower quadrant (LLQ) pain, fever, and leukocytosis in an older adult are highly suggestive of this condition.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of constant, aching left lower quadrant abdominal pain. He reports associated nausea and a low-grade fever at home. He has a history of chronic constipation and hypertension. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 145/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows localized tenderness and guarding in the left lower quadrant without rebound tenderness. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 13,500/mm³. Which of the following is the most appropriate imaging study to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A barium enema can visualize diverticula but is contraindicated in acute diverticulitis. The introduction of contrast under pressure into an inflamed colon carries a high risk of perforation. Furthermore, this study cannot visualize extraluminal pathology such as pericolic fat stranding or abscess formation.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasonography can be used to evaluate abdominal pain and may show signs of diverticulitis, such as a thickened bowel wall or a hypoechoic pericolic collection. However, it is highly operator-dependent, and its utility is often limited by overlying bowel gas in the left lower quadrant.

C) CORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast is the imaging modality of choice to confirm the diagnosis of acute diverticulitis. It is highly sensitive and specific for identifying characteristic findings such as colonic diverticula, bowel wall thickening, and pericolic fat stranding. Crucially, it can also detect and stage complications that affect management, such as abscess formation, fistula, obstruction, or perforation. Intravenous contrast enhances visualization of the bowel wall and helps delineate any abscess collections, which is critical for determining the need for inpatient admission, IV antibiotics, or percutaneous drainage.

D) INCORRECT:

While colonoscopy is the gold standard for visualizing diverticulosis (the underlying condition), it is contraindicated during an episode of acute diverticulitis. The insufflation of air into the colon during the procedure creates a significant risk of perforating the inflamed and weakened bowel wall, which could lead to peritonitis. A colonoscopy is typically recommended 6–8 weeks after the acute episode has resolved to evaluate the extent of disease and rule out malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominal plain films are generally not helpful in diagnosing uncomplicated diverticulitis, as their findings are often normal. While they can be used as an initial screen for other causes of abdominal pain and may show signs of complications like a bowel obstruction or a large perforation (free air under the diaphragm), they lack the sensitivity to diagnose diverticulitis itself or to detect more subtle complications like microperforation or abscess formation.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of left lower quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis is highly suggestive of acute diverticulitis. The chosen imaging study should not only confirm the diagnosis but also evaluate for potential complications.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with 2 days of progressive left lower quadrant pain and low-grade fever. He reports altered bowel habits, ranging from constipation to small-volume diarrhea, but no significant changes in appetite or overt blood in stool. He does not recall prior episodes. Examination reveals marked tenderness over the left lower quadrant with guarding and mild rebound. Laboratory evaluation shows normal serum electrolytes (see lab result and report).

Temperature
38.2°C



Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
14.6 × 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L


Abdominal imaging: Segmental colonic wall thickening
Which diagnosis best explains this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease often begins in younger patients and affects the terminal ileum and right colon. It presents with chronic inflammation and skip lesions, not acute left lower quadrant pain. The patient's age, acute symptom onset, and lack of chronic gastrointestinal complaints argue against Crohn disease.

B) CORRECT:

Diverticulitis manifests with left lower quadrant pain, low-grade fever, and leukocytosis, indicating colonic inflammation. Imaging shows segmental colonic wall thickening, often in the sigmoid colon, where diverticula are common. This condition results from microperforation of diverticula, leading to localized inflammation and possible abscess formation. Clinical findings such as tenderness, guarding, and mild rebound tenderness suggest peritoneal irritation. Altered bowel habits, including constipation and small-volume diarrhea, align with colonic inflammation affecting motility.

Key learning point: Left lower quadrant pain with guarding, rebound tenderness, and leukocytosis in adults is highly suggestive of diverticulitis, an inflammation of diverticula in the colon.

C) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis typically presents with continuous mucosal involvement starting at the rectum, not segmental thickening. It often involves chronic, relapsing episodes with bloody diarrhea, unlike the acute pain and altered bowel habits described. The patient's age and acute presentation with peritoneal signs further reduce the likelihood of ulcerative colitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Ischemic colitis typically presents with sudden, crampy pain and rectal bleeding, often due to compromised blood flow. The absence of significant gastrointestinal bleeding and a history of cardiovascular issues, along with the marked leukocytosis and localized tenderness, suggest an inflammatory process rather than ischemia.
